question.content:
An electromagnetic wave in free space travels along the negative $y$ direction. The magnetic field at a certain point in the path of the wave is observed to be $\bold B=3\times10^{-5}\ \text T\ \hat k$ at a certain time.

**What is the electric field $\bold E$ at that point and time?**

[[☃ radio 1]]

hints.content:
##Strategy

Here are two statements that give incomplete information to solve this problem:

- The speed of the electromagnetic wave is related to the magnitude of the electric and magnetic field.

- The direction of propagation of the wave is the direction of the cross-product of the two fields.

Let's try and remember the relations these statements are hinting at.

##Solution

The speed of the electromagnetic wave can be found using the expression $v=\dfrac{|\bold E|}{|\bold B|}$. Since the wave is in free space, the speed of light can be taken as $3\times10^8\ \dfrac{\text m}{\text s}$.

On solving, we get,

$|\bold E|=9\times10^3\ \dfrac{\text N}{\text C}$

[[☃ explanation 1]]

The direction of propagation, let's call it $\bold {\hat S}$, is the direction of the cross product $\bold {\hat E} \times {\bold {\hat B}}$. So,

$\begin{align}
\maroonD{\bold {\hat S}} &= \bold { \blueE{\hat E}} \times {\bold {\goldE{\hat B}}} \\\\
\Rightarrow \maroonD{-\hat j}&= \bold { \blueE{\hat E}} \times {{\goldE{\hat k}}} 
 \end{align}$

This equation implies that $\bold { \blueE{\hat E}} = \blueE{\hat i}$.

[[☃ explanation 1]]

options.explanation:
Here are two ways we can use $\maroonD{-\hat j} = \bold { \blueE{\hat E}} \times {{\goldE{\hat k}}}$ to find $\bold { \blueE{\hat E}}$ :

- We can use the right hand rule for cross-products. $\bold { \blueE{\hat E}}$ should point in a direction such that on curling the fingers from $\bold { \blueE{\hat E}}$ to ${{\goldE{\hat k}}}$, our thumb should point in the $\maroonD{-\hat j}$ direction. On doing this, we will be able to see that $\bold { \blueE{\hat E}}=\blueE{\hat i}$ is the correct direction.

- We can also use the diagram below to remember the results we get from applying the right-hand rule. 

[[☃ image 1]]

If we go clockwise, we use positive signs, and if we go counter-clockwise, we use negative signs.

Clockwise $\circlearrowright$ | Anticlockwise $\circlearrowleft$ 
- | - 
$\hat i \times \hat j = \hat k$ | $\hat j \times \hat i = -\hat k$
$\hat j \times \hat k = \hat i$ | $\hat k \times \hat j = -\hat i$
$\hat k \times \hat i = \hat j$ | $\hat i \times \hat k = -\hat j$

hints.content:
The electric field at that point and time is:

$9\times10^3\ \dfrac{\text N}{\text C}\ \hat i$.
